idTips: Unmistakeable large, yellow and black butterfly with long 'tails' on the hindwings
habitats: Fens and marshes in the Norfolk Broads, but wanders to other habitats including gardens. Also occurs as a scarce immigrant across southern Britain.
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small mottled brown and grey butterfly unlike any others. Distinguished from similar-looking moths by thickened tips of antennae (moths have pointed or feathery antennae)
habitats: Open, sunny places including chalk grassland, coasts, woodland clearings, heathland and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small grey and white chequered butterfly unlike any others.
habitats: Unimproved grassland, woodland clearings and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Brown wings chequered with golden yellow spots distinguish from other skippers
habitats: Damp grassland in open woodland and wood edges in western Scotland. Also in woodland rides in a Northamptonshire landscape, where the butterfly has recently been reintroduced.
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Plain orange forewings held up at an angle. Distinguished from Small Skipper by glossy black underside of tip of antennae
habitats: Sunny grasslands, verges, woodland clearings and coast with areas of long grass
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Plain orange forewings held up at an angle. Distinguished from Essex Skipper by orange/brown underside of tip of antennae
habitats: Grassland, downs, verges, woodland clearings and other places with long grass
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Dull brownish-orange forewings held up at an angle. Small size and dull colour distinguish from other orange skippers. Female has a crescent of brighter orange on the forewing.
habitats: Chalk and limestone grassland in south Dorset
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Forewings held up at an angle. Pearly-white spots on the underside of the wings distinguish from other orange skippers
habitats: Chalk grassland with short turf in southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Forewings held up at an angle. Mottled pattern of dark markings distinguishes from other orange skippers
habitats: A variety of sunny habitats with long grass
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Small size, delicate flight and shaded grey underside of hindwing distinguish from other whites
habitats: Sheltered grassland in woodland rides and clearings, hedgerows and undercliffs in England and Wales
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small size, delicate flight and shaded grey underside of hindwing distinguish from other whites.
habitats: Sheltered, flowery grassland in meadows, woodland, dunes, verges and quarries in Ireland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Medium Priority

idTips: The male's bright-orange wing-tips are diagnostic. Females have grey-black wing-tips but the green camouflage pattern on underside of hindwing distinguishes from other whites.
habitats: Many, but especially damp grassy habitats, hedges and verges
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Prominent black tip to forewing which extends equally down both sides of the forewing, distinguishes from Small White
habitats: Many, but particularly gardens, allotments and farmland where cabbages are grown
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Black tip to forewing less prominent and does not extend as far down the wing as on Large White
habitats: Many, but particularly gardens, allotments and farmland where cabbages are grown
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Distinctive dark lines along the underside wing veins separates it from other white butterflies
habitats: Many, but favours damp areas
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Mustard-yellow wings without points distinguish from male Brimstone
habitats: Any, particularly flowery places in southern Britain
ukStatus: Regular migrant and summer-breeding species. Possibly overwintering at sheltered sites on the south coast of England.

idTips: Males are a deep, bright lemon-yellow with females being paler. They have pointed ‘leaf-shaped’ wings which can help to distinguish them from other species.
habitats: Many, particularly woodland, road verges and hedgerows
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Unmistakeable, very large orange and black butterflies with white spots around wing edges and on body
habitats: Flowery places, including gardens, near coasts
ukStatus: Scarce migrant, not breeding or overwintering in the UK

idTips: Golden-orange with marbling of brown lines distinguishes from other browns
habitats: Grassland with bare ground, particularly around the coast but also on field edges and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Dark chocolate-brown wings flecked with cream or yellowish spots distinguish from other browns
habitats: Woodland, but also tall, sheltered grass in gardens, parks and hedgerows
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Orange-brown wings, cream-ringed eyespots on underside and habitat distinguish from other browns. Some individuals lack eyespots and closely resemble Small Heaths
habitats: Bogs and moors in northern Britain
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small size and orange wings distinguish from other browns. Can be very similar to some forms of Large Heath. Never rests with its wings open
habitats: Dry grasslands such as downs, heaths and on coasts, but also verges, moors, woodland clearings and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small, mainly brown butterfly with row of black spots (without white pupils) on wings
habitats: Mountain grassland in Scotland and the Lake District
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Dark brown wings with orange band containing multiple eyespots
habitats: Damp, sheltered grasslands in Scotland, plus two limestone grassland sites in northern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Underside of wings have distinctive eyespots each typically consisting of a cream spot with a black ring and a white centre
habitats: Tall, damp grass in woodland or pasture, and along hedgerows and verges
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: A generally brown butterfly on upperwing with some orange (the similar but smaller Gatekeeper generally appears more orange with some brown). Meadow browns of both sexes have a single black eyespot near tip of forewing - usually containing a single white pupil. The absence of tiny pale dots on underside of hindwing distinguishes from Gatekeeper when wings are closed.
habitats: Sunny grasslands
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: A fairly small butterfly which gives the impression of being predominantly orange with some brown (often mistaken for Meadow Brown which is larger and generally brown with some orange). Single black eyespot on forewing normally has two white pupils (c.f. Meadow Brown which has one white pupil). Small white spots on the hindwing underside distinguish it from Meadow Brown when wings are closed.
habitats: Long grass sheltered by hedgerows, scrub or woodland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Medium Priority

idTips: Unmistakable black and white chequered pattern
habitats: Tall grass on chalk and limestone grassland, coast, verges, woodland and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Mottled brown and grey pattern on underside distinguishes from other browns. Never rests with its wings open
habitats: Open areas with bare ground patches, mainly on coast but also heathland, chalk grassland, quarries and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small size and silvery spots on underside of hindwing distinguish from most other fritillaries. Difficult to distinguish from Small Pearl-bordered Fritillary, but has fewer silvery spots on hindwing underside.
habitats: Open woodland and bracken slopes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small size and silvery spots on underside of hindwing distinguish from most other fritillaries. Difficult to distinguish from Pearl-bordered Fritillary, but has more silvery spots on hindwing underside.
habitats: Many, including woodland clearings, damp grassland, moor, bracken-slopes and coast
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Large silver spots on hindwing underside distinguish from other fritillaries
habitats: Open sunny places
ukStatus: Scarce migrant with occasional evidence of breeding and overwintering in the UK

idTips: Large butterfly with silvery stripes on hindwing underside
habitats: Woodland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Large butterfly, with large white spots on hindwing underside. Difficult to distinguish from High Brown Fritillary, which has red-ringed spots on underside.
habitats: Bracken slopes, chalk and limestone grassland, coast, moors and woodland clearings
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Large butterfly, with row of red-ringed white spots on hindwing underside that distinguish from the very similar Dark Green Fritillary
habitats: Bracken slopes and woodland clearings
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Dark wings with broad white stripe. Rows of black spots on underside distinguish from Purple Emperor
habitats: Woodland in mid and southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Male: Very large size and beautiful purple sheen on upper wing in sunlight. Unlike the similar White Admiral there are no rows of black spots on underside, but large orange-fringed eye spot is diagnostic.Female: Very large size, dark upper wings with broad white stripe. Underside same as for male.
habitats: Woodland in mid and southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Distinctive pattern of brilliant red stripes on black wings and with small white patches near wing tip
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Salmon-pink to pale orange wings with distinctive pattern of black and white patches
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Regular migrant and summer-breeding species

idTips: Distinctive large eyespots on rich purple-red wings
habitats: Any, including woodland and gardens
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Orange-red wings with black and yellow band along front edge and white patch near tip. Blue spots around margin
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Distinctive dark brown-purple wings with blue border and pale wing edge
habitats: Usually near trees or scrub
ukStatus: Scarce migrant that can overwinter. No evidence of breeding in the UK.

idTips: Very similar to Small Tortoiseshell, but distinguished by yellowy rather than white patch near forewing tip and additional dark spot on forewing
habitats: Usually wooded areas
ukStatus: Currently a scarce migrant that appears to be recolonising parts of southern England

idTips: Scalloped or ‘ragged’ wing edges distinguish from all other butterflies
habitats: Woodland and other places with trees inlcuding gardens
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Mixture of cream, orange and brown chequered markings distinguish from other fritillaries
habitats: Damp grassland and heaths, chalk and limestone grassland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Geographical location and habitat, as well as beautifully patterned underwing, distinguish from other fritillaries
habitats: Coastal grasslands on the Isle of Wight
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small with darker wings than other fritillaries
habitats: Woodland clearings and sheltered heathland in southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Small size distinguishes from other butterflies with orange-brown chequered markings (fritillaries)
habitats: Sheltered chalk and limestone grassland or woodland clearings
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Bright metallic copper-coloured forewing with dark black-brown spots and fringe is unlike any other butterflies
habitats: Many, including dry grassland, heathland, moorland and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Medium Priority

idTips: Short tail on each hindwing. Bright orange-brown undersides distinguish from other hairstreaks
habitats: Hedges, scrub and woodland edge in distinct areas of southern Britain
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Medium Priority

idTips: Irridescent purple sheen on upperside of wings, short tail on hindwing. Silvery underside of wings distinguish from other hairstreaks
habitats: Oak trees in woods, hedges and scrub, even in parks and gardens
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Bright green undersides distinguish from all other butterflies
habitats: Many, including chalk grassland, moors, heaths, woodland clearings, bogs and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Short tail on each hindwing. 'W'-shaped white line on hindwing underside distinguishes from other hairstreaks
habitats: Elm trees in woods, hedges and scrub
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Short tail on each hindwing. Row of black spots on hindwing underside distinguishes from other hairstreaks
habitats: Tall blackthorn thickets in woods and hedgerows in English midlands
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Purply-blue wings with a tail on each hindwing. Wavy white lines on underside distinguish from other blue butterflies
habitats: Sightings tend to be in sunny grasslands or gardens
ukStatus: Scarce migrant and summer-breeding species, but unable to overwinter in the UK

idTips: Small size and plain, dark grey-brown wings distinguish from other blues
habitats: Dry, sheltered grasslands, including chalk, limestone, coast, quarries and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Medium Priority

idTips: Wings are blue on upperside and pale silvery-blue with small black dots but no orange spots on underside
habitats: Gardens, parks, hedgerows and woodland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Large size and large black spots on forewing distinguish from other blues
habitats: Unimproved dry limestone or coastal grassland in southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Male: Small size, habitat and black border around blue wings help to distinguish from other blues. Defining characteristic is row of tiny, metallic blue dots on underside of hindwing.Female: Can have brown or blue wings. Small size and habitat help to distinguish from other female blues. Defining characteristic is row of tiny, metallic blue dots on underside of hindwing
habitats: Usually lowland heathland, but also sometimes on chalk and limestone grassland and dunes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Difficult to distinguish from female Common Blue - hindwing underside of Common Blue has uppermost pair of spots in . . pattern as opposed to : pattern in Brown Argus
habitats: Many, including chalk and limestone grassland, coast and dunes, heath, woodland clearings, fallow fields and brownfield sites
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Prominent white spot in middle of each forewing distinguishes from other blues, but not all individuals have this spot. Georgraphic location and fainter underwing spots distinguish from Brown Argus
habitats: Unimproved, sheltered grassland in northern Britain
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Male: Bright blue wing with plain white edge distinguish from other blues.Female: Brown or blueish wing with orange spots near wing edge. Plain white wing edges distinguish from Chalkhill and Adonis Blue. Difficult to distinguish from Brown Argus - hindwing underside of Common Blue has uppermost pair of spots in . . pattern as opposed to : pattern in Brown Argus
habitats: Many, particularly sunny, sheltered places
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Male: Brilliant sky-blue wings with black lines crossing the white wing edge distinguish from other bluesFemale: Difficult to distinguish from female Chalkhill Blue, but black spots on wing upperside are edged with blue in Adonis Blue
habitats: Chalk and limestone grassland in southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority

idTips: Male: Pale, powder blue wings with black lines crossing white wing edge distinguish from other blues Female: Difficult to distinguish from female Adonis Blue, but black spots on wing upperside are edged with white in Chalkhill Blue
habitats: Chalk and limestone grassland in southern England
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: High Priority

idTips: Silvery-gold markings on the wing distinguish the males from other Swift moths, which have white markings. Flies in late afternoon, dusk and dawn
habitats: Usually found around Bracken in woodland, scrub and open places
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late May - late August, with the peak in late June and early July

idTips: Six crimson spots on each forewing distinguishes from other Burnet moths
habitats: Flowery grasslands including downland, woodland rides and sand dunes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: June to August, peaking in mid- to late July

idTips: Large size, white spot and cream band are distinctive. The darker brown males fly during the day, the larger, paler females are nocturnal
habitats: Many habitats with woody plants, including heaths, moors, hedgerows, scrub and woodland edge
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: June to August, peaking in early August

idTips: Parallel cream stripes and lack of spot on forewing. Males fly during the day, the greyer females at night
habitats: Open habitats including grasslands, heaths, moors and dunes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: May to mid-July, peaking in early June

idTips: Large eye spots on each wing. Males fly by day, females are nocturnal
habitats: Many, including heaths and moors, hedgerows and woodland rides and bogs and fens
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: April and May, peaking in late April

idTips: Distinctive hovering flight while drinking nectar with very long proboscis. Larger size and white spots along sides of body distinguish from Bee-flies
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Regular migrant and summer-breeding species, although some may successfully hibernate
whenToSee: Any month but mainly June to October, with peaks in late June/early July and early September

idTips: Darker central band across brown forewings and dark diagonal line at wing tip. Nocturnal but easily disturbed from vegetation during the day
habitats: Open habitats including grasslands, heaths, rides, road verges and dunes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late June to early September, with peak at the end of July / beginning of August

idTips: White or off-white wings with irregular dark stripe across each forewing. Nocturnal but easily disturbed from vegetation during the day
habitats: Most habitats, including grasslands, scrub, wetlands, hedgerows and woodland clearings
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mid-May to mid-August, with a peak in early June

idTips: Varies from bright yellow to brown but always with many thin wavy lines across the wings. Mainly flies after dusk but easily disturbed during the day
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late May to mid-September, with greatest numbers in July and August

idTips: Grey brown with a wavy white stripe that contains a thin dark line. Nocturnal but easily disturbed from vegetation during the day
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: April to September, with peak numbers in late July and August

idTips: Black or dark brown with white fringe to wing tips
habitats: Grasslands, including along hedgerows and woodland edge
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late May to late July, peaking in late June

idTips: Small and whitish with several pale brown stripes across the wings. Flies in the daytime, particularly near dusk
habitats: Grasslands, sand dunes and coastal shingle
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: May to August, with peak in early June

idTips: White wings with yellow stripes and extensive black spotting. Mainly nocturnal but sometimes flies during the day
habitats: Gardens, woods and hedgerows, plus moorland in northern Scotland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: June to mid-September, peaking in early August

idTips: Yellow to white wings strongly chequered with sharp brown lines. Often rests with wings half raised
habitats: Open habitats including farmland, grasslands, dunes, heaths and moors
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: May to September in the south, June and July in the north

idTips: Pale brown wings with a dark spot on each forewing and a straight pale line edged in dark brown. Nocturnal but very easily disturbed from vegetation during the day
habitats: Wherever Bracken grows
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mid-April to mid-July, peaking in early June

idTips: Bright yellow wings with numerous large brown spots
habitats: Mainly open woodland and scrub
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late April to late June, with a peak in late May

idTips: Wings vary from whitish grey to yellowy brown, often heavily speckled, and with several dark stripes. Male has strongly feathered antennae
habitats: Moorland, heathland and some grasslands
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: April to early August, with peak in late May and early June

idTips: Rests with wings folded vertically, like a butterfly, showing a white stripe on brown wings
habitats: Conifer woodland and plantations
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: May to early August, peaking at end of June

idTips: Orange-brown males are active during the day, often flying high along trees and hedgerows. Females are flightless and remain on their coccoon
habitats: Wide range of habitats with trees or scrub
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late June to late October, with numbers reaching a peak at the end of August

idTips: Forewings of the male are yellow with a pink fringe and a pink central spot. Often flies during the day but also active at night
habitats: Mainly heaths and moors but also some calcareous grassland and woodland clearings
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mainly end of May to mid-July, peaking in mid-June, but small numbers sometimes seen in August and early September in the south

idTips: Irredescent black forewings with large white and yellow spots. Scarlet and black hindwings and abdomen. Flies by day and at night
habitats: Mainly damp places such as meadows, wetlands, riverbanks and along the coast, but also seen in gardens and woodland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: End of May to end of July, peaking in late June

idTips: Zebra-striped forewing and bright red, orange or yellow hindwing. Active during the day and at night
habitats: Gardens, hedgerows, coastal habitats and disturbed ground
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: July to early September, with a peak in early August

idTips: Black forewing with red stripe and spots and a red hindwing. Mainly nocturnal but sometimes disturbed during the day
habitats: Grasslands, farmland, dunes and other open places
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mid-April to mid-August, with numbers peaking in early June

idTips: Greeny brown wings with broad purple stripes, although the stripes may be reduced or even absent on some moths
habitats: Chalk and limestone grasslands, heaths, moors and sand dunes
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: April to August, with peaks in early June and late July

idTips: Striped brown forewings and yellowy hindwings. Sometimes confused with Dingy Skipper butterfly
habitats: Grasslands and open areas in woodland
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mid-April to mid-July, peaking in late May and early June

idTips: The cream lines on each forewing resemble the profile of a witch, with long nose and chin and a small dark eye
habitats: Rough, grassy habitats such as heaths, downs, woodland rides, flowery meadows, verges and embankments
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: May to early July, with a peak at the end of May

idTips: Grey brown forewing with silver "y" mark in centre. Hindwing pale with darker fringe. Active during the day and at night
habitats: Any
ukStatus: Regular migrant and summer-breeding species
whenToSee: Any month but mainly May to October, with peak in July and early August

idTips: Small size and bright yellow band across black hindwings are distinctive. Most likely to be confused with micro-moths such as Mint Moth
habitats: Flower-rich grasslands
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late April to mid-June, peaking in the second half of May

idTips: Long, branched creamy white stripe on each forewing. Flies during the day and at night
habitats: Grasslands and moors
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Late June to mid-September, with a peak in late July

idTips: Reddish brown forewing with white stripes and spots, yellow hindwing with black fringe
habitats: Heaths and moors
ukStatus: Butterfly Conservation UK threat level: Lower Priority
whenToSee: Mid-April to early September, with numbers peaking in late July and early August
